description: From Middle English hobblen, hobelen, akin to Middle Dutch hoblen, hobbelen (Modern Dutch hobbelen).

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural) One of the short straps tied between the legs of unfenced horses, allowing them to wander short distances but preventing them from running off.
(archaic, informal) A difficult situation; a scrape.
examples: "Saddle a horse—any horse—only let him be sure and fleet," cried Ashwoode, "and I'll pay you his price thrice over!""Well, it's a bargain," replied the groom, promptly; "I don't like to see a gentleman caught in a hobble, if I can help him out of it.  […]

entries.meaning: (dialect, UK and Newfoundland) An odd job; a piece of casual work.

verbs.description: hobble (third-person singular simple present hobbles, present participle hobbling, simple past and past participle hobbled)

entries.meaning: To fetter by tying the legs; to restrict (a horse) with hobbles.
examples: you hobble your old horse and turn him grazing
The friar was hobbling the same way too.
The hobbling versification, the mean diction.
